item.title: No title
item.description: SAN FRANCISCO - Who is Satoshi Nakamoto? For many in the tech world, the identity of bitcoin's elusive creator has been a long-running parlor game. And the speculation might not be over. Australian entrepreneur Craig Steven Wright, who announced Monday that he founded the digital currency , convinced at least one longtime bitcoin contributor that he's the real deal.

item.title: Bitcoin has a governance problem, no matter who created it - Tech2
item.description:
Bitcoin has a governance problem, no matter who created it - Tech2

As one would-be father of bitcoin falls by the wayside, squabbling among the web-based currency's lead developers is exposing a fundamental flaw: it must evolve to meet growing demand, but may lack a governance structure to achieve this.

item.title: Liberty Reserve Creator Sentenced To 20 Years Jail Time
item.description:
Liberty Reserve Creator Sentenced To 20 Years Jail Time

Bitcoin was not the first type of online money to be ever created, as it was preceded by E-Gold and Liberty Reserve, to name a few. The creator of Liberty Reserve was sentenced to 20 years in prison on May 6th.

item.title: Is There A Bitcoin Connection Between The CIA and Satoshi Nakamoto?
item.description:
Is There A Bitcoin Connection Between The CIA and Satoshi Nakamoto?

While it is certainly true Gavin Andresen gave a talk on Bitcoin at the CIA headquarters a few years ago, nothing has come from that connection ever since. The mystery of Satoshi Nakamoto will remain a topic of substantial discussion for several years to come.

item.title: Counterparty and the Japanese Digital Currency Market - NEWSBTC
item.description:
Counterparty and the Japanese Digital Currency Market - NEWSBTC

Counterparty has gained lot of traction in Japan, the country that was least expected to get back on the cryptocurrency bandwagon so soon after the Mt Gox fiasco. Read more... Since Bitcoin started gaining attention across the world, Japan was the first country to face the burnt, all thanks to the Mt.

item.title: Exclusive: Jeff Garzik's Stealthy Ploy To Get Bitcoin Onto Private Blockchains
item.description:
Exclusive: Jeff Garzik's Stealthy Ploy To Get Bitcoin Onto Private Blockchains

Longtime Bitcoin core developer Jeff Garzik acknowledges Bitcoins' branding problem. "The bitcoin name, in terms of marketing, is something that larger institutions are somewhat reluctant to deal with, related to the history with Mt Gox and Silk Road, most notably." Garzik bemoans how this reputation follows the word Bitcoin.

item.title: Security Experts Infiltrate Locky Ransomware C&C Server
item.description:
Security Experts Infiltrate Locky Ransomware C&C Server

Bitcoin ransomware has been the front and center of media attention in recent months, but luckily, security researchers are inching closer towards a solution.

item.title: Coinbase, Bitpay and Bitcoin Core
item.description:
Coinbase, Bitpay and Bitcoin Core

A website shows their services can be purchased via Coinbase and Bitpay. I searched for information and found Bitcoin Core from bitcoin.org/en/choose-your-wallet and I think it is very popular among

item.title: IBM Brings Blockchains to the Cloud - Bitcoin News
item.description:
IBM Brings Blockchains to the Cloud - Bitcoin News

Recently, IBM Also read: Bitcoin's Next Adoption Phase Imminent as Public Interest Surges announced a new blockchain architecture based in the cloud after working with "hundreds of clients, startups, and developers." The protocol is a cloud service that address security standards, regulatory compliance with Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS 140-2) and Evaluation Assurance Levels (EAL).

item.title: How Should We Abbreviate Bitcoin and Ether?
item.description:
How Should We Abbreviate Bitcoin and Ether?

Whilst the term 'BTC' has long been the standard abbreviation for Bitcoin, there is a growing call from the Bitcoin community and exchanges in particular to begin referring to it as 'XBT'. However, its semi-pseudonymous creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, still refers to it as ' BTC '. What is a proper way to abbreviate Bitcoin?
